WSL Institute for Snow and Avalanche Research SLF
Site description: The WSL Institute for Snow and Avalanche Research SLF (WSL/SLF) took over the responsibility for the continuation of those measurements. All ASRB instruments were mounted on the automatic station Stilli (SLF) (0-756-1-927792), which primarily delivers nivo-meteorological data to the Swiss Inter cantonal Measurement and Information System (IMIS) network (ID: SLF2).
Predominant surface cover: Mosaic grassland (50-70%) / forest or shrubland (20-50%) (Surface cover types (GlobCover2009))
Topography or bathymetry: A valley bottom at middle relative elevation within mountains of high altitude

Supervising organization: WSL Institute for Snow and Avalanche Research SLF
Site description: The Cryonet station Davos Stilli (SLF) is located close to the WSL/SLF offices, even though outside its premises. The station belongs to the Swiss Inter cantonal Measurement and Information System (IMIS) network (ID: SLF2) but is owned by WSL/SLF. _ GCW attributes: CryoNet reference research station in an Alpine valley. _ Additional cryosphere measurements: Snow surface temperature Snow temperatures at 25, 50, and 100 cm above ground _
Predominant surface cover: Mosaic grassland (50-70%) / forest or shrubland (20-50%) (Surface cover types (GlobCover2009))
Topography or bathymetry: A valley bottom at middle relative elevation within rises of high altitude

Supervising organization: WSL Institute for Snow and Avalanche Research SLF
Site description: Daily snow depth measurements in Davos date back to the late 1800s and were performed at various location within the limits of the town. This is nicely exemplified by the time series dating back to 1893 and associated with today's SwissMetNet station DAVOS (0-20000-0-06784). On the other hand, in winter 1946 the Rhaetian Railway (RhB) started to measure snow depth near the train station of Davos Dorf. It was not before winter 1968 that the station was relocated near the current building of the WSL Institute for Snow and Avalanche Research SLF (WSL/SLF) in the Davos valley bottom, where snow depth, depth of snowfall and water equivalent of snow cover (SWE) are still measured nowadays. Parallel to the snow depth measurements of RhB, the Swiss Federal Institute for Snow and Avalanche Research (SFISAR) took SWE measurements at Bühl in Davos Dorf from 1947 to 1950 and at the Kurpark in Davos Platz from 1951 to 1970. These measurements by the Rhaetian Railway, SFISAR, and WSL/SLF make up the second long term series of manned snow observations in Davos. Nowadays the site for manual snow observations is located close to the WSL/SLF offices, even though outside its premises, and near the automatic station Davos Stilli (SLF). The Davos SLF observer station belongs to the operational observer network of the Swiss Avalanche Warning Service and is part of the Swiss GCOS snow station network. _ GCW attributes: GCW contributing reference station in an Alpine valley. _
Predominant surface cover: Mosaic grassland (50-70%) / forest or shrubland (20-50%) (Surface cover types (GlobCover2009))
Topography or bathymetry: A valley bottom at middle relative elevation within rises of high altitude

WSL Institute for Snow and Avalanche Research SLF
Site description: The Flüela station is part of the Swiss Permafrost Monitoring Network (PERMOS; www.permos.ch). The station is important to monitor and analyse the evolution of ground temperature, permafrost thickness, and the degradation of ground ice in talus deposits, which are important forms of debris storage in mountain environments and can cause mass movements, subsidence or instability of mountain infrastructure. It is the first permafrost research site of the Swiss Alps (Haeberli 1975). Two boreholes were drilled in 2002, instrumented with thermistor chains, one being still in use with ground temperatures measured down to 25 m. The station also delivers data to the Swiss Inter cantonal Measurement and Information System (IMIS) network used by the Swiss Avalanche Warning Service WSL/SLF (https://whiterisk.ch/fr/conditions/measurements/station/IMIS/FLU2). _ Additional cryosphere measurements: - Snow (gentle grassy slope): Snow surface temperature Snow temperatures at 25, 50, and 100 cm above ground (from 2003 to 2020) - Permafrost (talus slope): Daily photographs of site and regular high resolution aerial photographs; Electrical Resistance Tomography (ERT) and seismic measurements were done in 1975 and from 2009 to 2012. _
Topography or bathymetry: A slope at middle relative elevation within rises of high altitude

Site description: The high alpine research station Jungfraujoch is situated on a mountain saddle between the two mountains Jungfrau (4158m asl) and Mönch (4099m asl). The station is located in the center of Europe at an altitude of 3580m asl and is surrounded by highly industrialized regions at much lower altitudes. This special geographical situation offers the opportunity to monitor background concentrations but also to investigate the transport of anthropogenic pollutants from the boundary layer to the free troposphere.
Programs/Network affiliation: AGAGE:Operational, EMEP:Operational, GAW Global:Operational, ICOS, NDACC:Operational

Supervising organization: Federal Office of Meteorology and Climatology MeteoSwiss
WSL Institute for Snow and Avalanche Research SLF
Site description: This station owned by WSL/SLF delivers data to the Swiss Inter cantonal Measurement and Information System (IMIS) automatic station network, an important component of the Swiss Avalanche Warning Service. _ GCW attributes: CryoNet reference station on an alpine meadow surrounded by a moor. _ Additional cryosphere measurements: Snow surface temperature Snow temperatures at 25, 50, and 100 cm above ground _
Surface roughness: Open (Open flat terrain; grass, few isolated obstacles)
Topography or bathymetry: A flat at middle relative elevation within rises of high altitude
